title-group.article-title: Epidemiology of injured e‐scooter riders at a major trauma service – the who, what, where and when?

sec.title: Background
sec.p: E‐scooter associated injury patterns are well described, but less is known about the riders. This study describes the epidemiological characteristics of injured riders with the aim of providing information for preventative strategies.

sec.title: Methods
sec.p: A retrospective review of prospectively collected data on admissions (2021) and all hospital presentations (2022–2023) to the Royal Melbourne Hospital, due to injury in a rider of an e‐scooter. Data collected were demographics (age, gender, postcode), drug and alcohol usage, helmet usage, circumstances of injury (how, where and when), reported speed, and insurance status. Data was analysed with multiple cross tabulations using two‐sided Fischer's exact test.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: Over the 3 years 562 cases were identified, with a median age 29 years (IQR 23–40), 383 (68.5%) were male. Alcohol (29.5%) and drug (10.9%) usage were prevalent. The majority (70.4%) “fell off” without collision, 274 were admitted, and 9.6% were major trauma. Alcohol usage was more likely seen in men (P = 0.006), in major trauma (P = 0.02) but showed no association with age. Speed over 20 km/h was seen in 38.5% when recorded and associated with drug usage and major trauma status but not alcohol. Medicare ineligibility patients (12.1%) were younger, more likely to be female (P = 0.012) and less likely to use drugs (P = 0.001) and alcohol (P < 0.001).

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: This hospital level data of injured e‐scooter riders has shown high prevalence of alcohol and drug usage and speeding, all of which were associated with more severe injury, and are hence prime targets for injury prevention.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: E‐scooters have rapidly become a popular method of transport in Melbourne along with many other urban environments. Whilst e‐scooter availability could potentially reduce motor vehicle usage, alleviate congestion and cut carbon emissions, there has been a surge in injuries associated with their use. Injury patterns and hospital costs have previously been described in our hospital 1 and are similar to what has been described elsewhere in Australia,2, 3, 4, 5, 6 New Zealand,7, 8 and worldwide, 9 with high alcohol and drug usage, and low helmet usage associated with these injuries. However, there is less described about the characteristics of the injured riders, which is important for the future development of injury prevention strategies.

The aim of this study is to describe the epidemiology (who, where, when and why) of e‐scooter riders who have been injured enough to present to the Royal Melbourne Hospital (RMH) between 2021 and 2023, and to identify potential targets for injury prevention by examining the associations between the variables of interest.

sec.title: Setting and design
sec.p: This study is a retrospective database analysis undertaken at the Royal Melbourne Hospital (RMH) between January 2021 and December 2023. The RMH is one of two adult Major Trauma Services in the state of Victoria and is situated within the City of Melbourne, one of three e‐scooter hire metropolitan trial zones, which commenced in February 2022. Inclusion criteria were either admission to RMH (2021) or presentation to RMH ED (2022–2023) as a result of an injury from an e‐scooter crash/fall, where the person was the rider. Those injured by e‐scooters whilst not riding, for example, pedestrians or passengers, plus riders of other e‐mobility devices such as e‐bicycles, e‐skateboards and electric mobility aids where excluded.

Cases were identified from the prospectively collected RMH Trauma Registry (RMH‐TR), noting that at the time there was no specific code or designation for e‐scooter as a mechanism of injury. The RMH‐TR was expanded from 1st January 2021, with ‘electric scooter’ reported as a specific data field under the transport category ‘other transport related circumstances’. Coders were trained to ensure accurate case identification. For the year of 2021, the usual inclusion criteria for the RMH‐TR were utilized, namely admission ≥24 h due to injury, with those reaching Victorian State Trauma System (VSTS) major trauma criteria receiving an extended dataset collection. For the years of 2022–2023, data collection was expanded so that all presentations to the RMH ED, regardless of admission status/length of stay were included. The 2021–2022 data was subjected to the same trauma data capture as for major trauma patients. Data collectors were instructed to collect as much pertinent information in the injury narrative as possible. This has resulted in a hospital level data for the year 2021–2022.

Datapoints collected included patient factors such as age, gender, comorbidity, injury circumstances (time of injury, time of admission, day of week, drug, and alcohol & helmet usage). Major trauma status was defined as per the Victorian State Trauma System guidelines and include any of (i) Injury Severity Score > 12, (ii) admission to ICU, (iii) major surgery to head/chest/abdomen/pelvis/spine <48 h from admission, (iv) death and (v) burns >20% TBSA. Discharge destination was considered from an ED perspective and defined as either (i) discharge from ED (ii) admitted then discharged from short stay unit (SSU) and (iii) admitted to ward. For description, we stratified by discharge from the Emergency department (ED) and admitted to either the ward or a Short Stay Unit (SSU). Alcohol & drug usage was defined as binary yes/no, with any evidence of usage considering as positive, such as patient giving a history of usage, clinician suspecting usage on examination or any value >0.0 g% on blood or breath test, noting that this does not necessarily imply alcohol or drug intoxication. Drug usage included any use of non‐prescription or illicit medications such as (but not limited to) marijuana, gamma hydroxybutyrate (GHB), non‐prescribed opioids and amphetamines. Postcode of residence was categorized as City of Melbourne, Other Melbourne suburbs, other Victoria, and Interstate/overseas. Those with a home postcode outside of Melbourne were further categorized as potential tourists. Circumstances were derived from the free text descriptor.

sec.title: Data categorization and analysis
sec.p: For factors describing the demographics and circumstances of the injury, all 3 year's data was analysed as one cohort. For analysis, several variables were categorized as follows: age as 15–34 y and 35 y+, time of day as workforce relevant 8‐h blocks (0600–1400–2200 h), and weekends were defined as Friday to Sunday inclusive, without consideration of public holidays. Time of admission was the most complete time datapoint and hence used for time‐based analyses. Event details were described as (i) collision with moving vehicle, (ii) collision with stationary vehicle (iii) fall avoiding traffic, all categorized as vehicle collisions, (iv) collision with person/bicycle/other scooter, (v) fall, no precipitant, and (vi) collision with stationary object, including a kerb. As there was some overlap, we further categorized event as into a binary traffic related yes/no, where traffic related included any interaction with a motor vehicle, stationary or moving, collision with other road users or falling off whilst avoiding road traffic. Hospital status was defined as a binary ineligible for Medicare versus compensable/Medicare/insured, the latter category included public Medicare eligible patients, privately insured patients and third‐party compensable patients (Traffic Accident Commission‐TAC, Workcover).

Summary data is presented as median and IQR's and percentages as appropriate. Univariate analysis of categorical variables was performed using two tailed Fischer's exact test with ‘significance’ set at a P‐value of 0.05. Multiple cross tabulations were performed with a hypothesis generating approach, rather than testing a specific hypothesis(es). Missing data was approached by utilizing a complete case analysis where relevant. Age was examined both as a categorical variable, with cut point decided by the distribution of the data, plus as a continuous variable, the later utilizing the Wilcoxon rank sum test as data were highly skewed to a younger age. Ethics approval was received from Melbourne Health HREC (QA2023117).

sec.title: Results
sec.p: For the three‐year study period, there were 562 presentations with a median age of 29 year (IQR 23–40) and just over two thirds were male 383 (68.2%) (Table 1). By year, in 2021 there were 34 presentations (admissions only), 232 (106 admissions) in 2022, and 296 (134 admissions) in 2023. Most 299 (53.2%) occurred on Friday/Saturday/Sunday and the most common time period of ED presentation was 1400–2200 h (37.5%).

sec.p: Persons were mostly healthy/non limiting comorbidity (91.0%) and low (1.9%) anticoagulant usage. The majority were classed as hospital/Medicare (73.1%) with 14.8% insured or compensable, and 12.1% Medicare ineligible. Just under 30 % (n = 166, 29.5%) had alcohol involvement, 61 (10.9%) had drug involvement and 201 (35.8%) had either or both. Helmet usage was undocumented for just under half 250 (44.5%), but for those where documentation was considered sufficient, 58.0% had helmet usage. Most 392 (70.4%) events were categorized as a ‘fall off’ e‐scooter with trafffic related collisions 103 (18.5%) next most common.

Alcohol usage was more likely to be seen in males (P = 0.006), but no evidence of an association with age group (P = 0.25). (Table 2). There was no evidence of an association between drug usage and either age (P = 0.75) nor gender (P = 0.15). Alcohol usage was more likely seen on the weekend (P = 0.001) and with presentations between 2200 and 0600 h (P < 0.001), but no such association was seen for drug usage (weekend P = 0.50, time of admission P = 0.76). There was moderate evidence for traffic related incidents being less likely to involve alcohol (P = 0.014), but there was no evidence for an association between type of event and alcohol nor drugs. Both alcohol (P < 0.001) and drug usage (P < 0.001) showed strong evidence of an association with reaching major trauma status.

caption.p: Associations of variables of interest with alcohol and drug usage

sec.p: Increasing age was associated with male gender (P = 0.001), but gender was not associated with time of admission nor day of week. Similarly, there was no evidence of association with gender and traffic related activity, event category. As age was available as a continuous variable, medians were compared with other binary variables of interest. Median age was higher in men (P = 0.001) and medicare eligible/compensable/insured (P = 0.001) and those admitted (P = 0.001), and younger for traffic related incidents (P‐0.0.054), but no difference was seen in speeding, drug nor alcohol usage. Time of presentation was associated with traffic related incidents (P = 0.026) and the weekdays were more likely to be traffic related, and weekends falling off incidents (P = 0.024).

Self‐reported speed was available for 247 (44.0%), with a median of 20 km/h, with 38.5% reporting speeds above this limit, up to a maximum of 80 km/h (Fig. 1). There was a strong evidence for an association for speed >20 km/h and drug usage (P < 0.001) but not alcohol usage (Table 3). Those who self‐reported speeding were more likely to be male (P < 0.001), suffer major trauma (P < 0.001), and less likely to be a Medicare ineligible (P < 0.009).

sec.p: Medicare ineligible patients were more likely to be female (P = 0.012) and younger (P < 0.001) when compared to those patients who were either compensable or covered by Medicare (Table 3). They were also less likely to be admitted (11.8% versus compensable/Medicare 28.5%), use alcohol (P < 0.001), and had no incidents of drug usage (P = 0.001). Potential tourists, based upon postcode of residence, were less likely associated with traffic incidents (P = 0.035), but there was no evidence of an association with age, gender alcohol or drug usage.

Table 4 compares alcohol and drug usage in that subset of e‐scooter riders reaching major trauma criteria between 2021 and 2023 with other modes of transport in the same time period from the RMH‐TR. Alcohol and drug usage were between two and six times more prevalent in e‐scooter riders than in other forms of transport.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: This large series of predominantly hospital level data describes available epidemiological features of the injured riders of e‐scooters presenting to a Major Trauma Service within the geographical area of the City of Melbourne e‐scooter trial zone. As described in other Australian studies, alcohol and drug usage was highly prevalent in this cohort. This study's alcohol prevalence of 29.5% is less than the Northern Territory (46%) 3 but similar to series from Western Australia (27%), 6 Queensland (27%, 26.7%) 2 and Auckland (23.3%), 7 noting the slightly different populations and definitions of alcohol usage. Illicit drug usage was less often described in the Australian & New Zealand context, but this study's prevalence of 10.9% is almost identical to WA's described 11%, 6 noting that the WA cohort was admitted trauma patients. This figure is comparable to a 10‐year study at the RMH, which showed the prevalence of drug usage prior to injury was 9.0%, although when looked at per annum, this increased from 4.8% in 2010 to 13.4% in 2020. 10 Alcohol usage decreased over that time, from 11.7% to 7.7% over the same decade, substantially less than the approximately 30% reported in e‐scooter studies.

One of the strongest associations was for both alcohol and drug usage with patients who were categorized as major trauma. Alcohol and drug usage has previously been demonstrated to be associated with poorer outcomes in our population of major trauma patients. 10

This finding suggests disassociating drug and alcohol usage with the riding of e‐scooters would be a prime target for prevention, not only as they would be intuitively more likely to have a crash, but also more likely to suffer serious injury. When we compared the proportion of alcohol and other drug usage in the major trauma population, we noticed substantially increased rates of usage of both compared to other modes of transport.

Although alcohol usage was widespread, males were more likely to have evidence of alcohol usage, and the overnight hours of 2200–0600 h the most likely time for presentation to the RMH Emergency Department. Unfortunately, it was not possible to discern usable data for the time of injury, as approximately half had a recorded timing of 2400 h, noting this is also both the default for unknown and a common time for injury for this mechanism of injury and alcohol related harm. However, it is conceivable that limitation of hire e‐scooter usage based on this time could potentially decrease the volume of e‐scooter associated harm presenting to our health services.

Helmet usage documentation was low, but as many presentations were for orthopaedic or soft tissue injuries of upper limbs, it is arguable that documentation of helmet usage is not relevant, hence not collected by the attending clinician. However, low helmet usage is another consistent theme in the literature and this study is concordant with that. The authors feel that the evidence from the literature of the benefit of helmet usage in bicycle riders 11 is at least in part transferrable e‐scooter riders, and this represents another avenue for injury prevention.

The interpretation of speed is challenged by missing data in just over a half, plus the data is self‐reported rather than objectively measured. However, the available data shows a wide range of speeds with just under a half reporting travel over the legal 20 km/h limit, noting the authors' held impression that persons naturally round down when reporting adverse incident related velocity to an authority. Hire e‐scooters are mechanically speed limited at 20 km/h, suggesting that those travelling over this limit are utilizing personal e‐scooters. The strong association of speed >20 km/h with drug usage, but not alcohol usage is noteworthy, and the increase in major trauma with higher speed is consistent with the laws of physics. There was no evidence of an association between higher speed and road traffic related incidents, time of week, or rider age. These data suggest there is a subgroup of males who use drugs, who are travelling at high speeds, both in traffic and out of traffic, and that when injured are more likely to be seriously injured.

When we looked at mechanism of injury, we noted that the majority of injuries have occurred when the rider ‘fell off’ without collision with an object or other vehicle. Injury narratives mostly described minor bumps on paths and kerbs, but many described just losing control and falling off, highlighting the inherent instability of the e‐scooter platform. We also categorized those occurring in traffic, which included collision with cars, both stationary and moving. Although there was a statistical association to suggest that traffic related crashes were less likely to involve alcohol usage, both groups were worryingly high at 20.0% (traffic related) and 31.9% (non‐traffic related). For traffic related presentations, the riders were younger and slightly more likely on a weekday (55.6%) versus the weekend, and in the afternoon, suggesting that although there is likely a proportion of commuter travel, e‐scooters are being utilized at all times of day and the week.

One subgroup of interest were the Medicare ineligible patients, which constituted 12.1% of this cohort, considerable higher than the medicare ineligible/non compensable rate of 2.0% seen in the RMH Trauma Registry. This is of particular concern as they could face considerable personal financial burden as a result of their hospitalization, and vice versa present a financial impact upon the health system. It is hypothesised that this subgroup could potentially consist of tourists or students, noting the roughly equal gender distribution, and younger age. A proportion may in fact have some form of insurance, particularly overseas students who study at educational institutions that mandate health insurance coverage, and were discharged from ED before this was ascertained. However, there is a subset of financially vulnerable e‐scooter users amongst this cohort, but these are more likely to present with less severe injuries, noting that none reached major trauma status. With the recent cessation of the e‐scooter hire system in the City of Melbourne there may be less of these presentations, (noting two other Melbourne council areas, the City of Yarra and the City of Port Phillip are continuing to participate) which sit either side of the City of Melbourne. Similarly, those identified as potential tourists based upon their postcode of residence, had little to differentiate from non‐tourists apart from a slight increase in alcohol usage, and were half as likely to be involved in a traffic related incident. The authors speculate from the available data, that although a reduction in hire e‐scooter availability will likely decrease the number of hospital presentations, it may disproportionately decrease the minor injuries, but those with major trauma will likely continue to present.

Limitations: It bears consideration that this manuscript describes statistical associations and is not methodologically designed to established causality. Hence caution should be utilized in interpretation. By way of example, there was strong evidence of an association between drug usage and speeding. It would be cognitively easy to attribute a causal relationship, that is, the drug usage causes speeding on e‐scooter. However, the relationship could be confounded by a third factor, for example both speeding on a e‐scooter and taking drugs may be a manifestation of a risk taking personality.

A further limitation of this dataset is that it does not differentiate between privately owned e‐scooter and hire scheme e‐scooters, noting that the RMH is within the City of Melbourne e‐scooter trial zone. It is anticipated that there may be differences in the persons riding hired e‐scooters versus personally owned e‐scooters and given that hire e‐scooters are speed limited, it could be inferred that those reporting travel of greater than 20 km/h are utilizing personal e‐scooters.

This single centre study presents hospital level data, but it is one of several hospitals located in the city of Melbourne and surround trial zones, and therefore only presents a proportion of the volume and type of persons injured in e‐scooter injuries. Although data was collected contemporaneously, data collection was subject to the quality of the ambulance case sheets and the medical record. Case identification was believed to be accurate, but once again subject to the correct documentation of e‐scooter, noting that the RMH‐TR data collectors were given a guideline for differentiating the differing forms of personal mobility devices. We utilized a binary definition of alcohol and drug usage that was essentially any usage preceding the crash in a timeframe thought relevant by the treating clinician. For half the cohort we had blood or breath analysis, the remaining were clinical judgement of the staff. This may lead to an over estimation of both alcohol and drug usage compared to other studies utilize a specific blood/breath/saliva/urine definition, but more appropriate or this cohort, many of whom were presenting with isolated limb soft tissue/bony injuries managed at an outpatient level. Postcodes of injury were not available, but postcodes of residence were, from which potential tourist status was imputed. Finally, the statistical methodology employed can only highlight associations – analysis is insufficient to suggest any causal relationship between variables. It is also noted that with multiple tests of association a type II error, of an association by chance is increased. We elected not to compensate for this with a Bonferroni adjustment, preferring to describe the finding without over interpreting them. Further investigation by testing specific hypotheses around alcohol and speeding with multivariate regression is planned.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: E‐scooters have fast become a substantial proportion of the Royal Melbourne Hospital workload. This hospital population of e‐scooter injuries shows some associations that may assist preventative strategies. There was a higher than expected proportion of medicare ineligible patients, who tended to be younger, less injured and less likely to use drugs or alcohol. Clear targets for prevention would be to drug & alcohol usage and reduce excessive speed, all of which are highly prevalent in this cohort and associated with more severe injury.
